title: At close of business on 28 April 2021, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 17 March 2021?
preds: Post credit crisis, it was called 'kicking the can down the road'. Now we call it 'hitting the snooze button'. I am inwardly wincing because I allotted 0% probability to the 'higher' bucket and my apologies to the Universe! 1% for the (very) highly unlikely possibility of negative interest rates!

Baseline – Current rate is set due to COVID-19’s impact on the US economy, setting the rate to 25bps.  Adjustments up –
-	Vaccine is speeding the return to normal in the economy (@ 13% with likely 3*30 Million more to receive over this time period – and adjust downward for time to be fully protected) Adjustments down
-	Spring travel might bring up COVID numbers, bringing a temporary depression on transactions
-	Continuing caution is being advised even after vaccine
-	Debts will be more expensive for the US gov to pay off if rates are adjusted. Already near zero and transactions likely to increase, lowering the rate is highly unlikely outside of a black swan.  The time period is a short adjustment time without major changes to the economic structure.

The target rate for March 17th was 0-0.25%. The target rate has remained at this level since April 1, 2020 and is expected to remain at this level for the next month at least. https://apps.newyorkfed.org/markets/autorates/fed%20funds
Following March meeting seems very unlikely there is a shift in April.
Moved same a bit higher. Really just moving round the edges but think 100 is too high by consensus.
Wishful Thinking that monetary policy will regain some semblance of sanity
I think it will be too early in the recovery for the FOMC to consider raising rates. Will need to see more data showing sequential improvements in demand and employment.

Assumptions:  Biden is president, Corona vaccination is at least 75% effective, no black swans.  Fed can't keep the target Range at 0 forever. New leadership will at least reconsider the current position. This timeframe only leaves 2 Fed official meetings before the end of this question.
Businesses will not be out of the woods; loans will need to be restructured.
Stay the course, we are not yet out of the Covid woods.
Nothing ever happens and there won't be room to go lower.
Seduced by the brief argument of @Halito + slight bias of optimism regarding the evolution of the pandemic.
This would be too soon in the new administration to begin a new strategy for the fed.  Check back this Summer.
You can take Jay Powell at his word.
4 months will not be long enough to know how well the economy is doing to make any changes to the rate.

Inflation isnt expected to rise any time soon. Interesting to see how inflation holds up with commodity prices surging and unemployment still being high. A cut from current levels looks rather unlikely too(considering the fed`s current stance on negative interest rates). The upper end of the rate is currently 25 bps.  
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-10/u-s-inflation-measure-rose-by-more-than-forecast-in-november

The central bank will be hesitant to make ANY rate changes until it is confident that the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to achieve its maximum employment and price stability goals. Status quo for the foreseeable future.

I think there have been 13 fed fund rate changes over the last 5 years. 8 meetings a year so roughly a third of meetings there has been a change. 5 years before that though there was 1 so 3% and 17.5% over the decade. There is also clearly grouping of these changes - I.e. after the first increase they happen repeatedly. Feels like April is likely too soon for a change - feels unlikely the force of the vaccine will be felt but probably a reluctance to cut even if covid is worse if the vaccine impact is nearly upon us. Also a commitment to catch up inflation now would keep rates low but I think overall a reluctance for negative rates. Overall feels like I want to have a low prob of change and be close to or exactly symmetrical. 3% (2011 through 2015 experience) feels too low given the world is probably fat tailed at the moment, although the policy discussions do have a lot in common with that period. 17.5% seems too high though given the clustering of changes and backdrops. Going for 6% and symmetrical cut or hike.
Fed will be feeling out the direction of new administration and no apparent incentive to increase funds rate
Everything points to it remaining the same. It will take more time for any type of recovery to happen.
Every single public statement from the says that is what is going to be for years to come.
Unlikely to hit inflation or employment targets by then and the FED has committed to low rates.
